questions.text: SARS-CoV-2 is believed to transmit primarily via:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • SARS-CoV-2 primarily spreads through respiratory droplets, which are expelled when an infected person talks, coughs, or sneezes
  • These droplets typically travel short distances (≤2 meters) and can directly contact the mucous membranes (eyes, nose, or mouth) of nearby individuals
  • Close contact remains the highest-risk setting for transmission

Explanation of other options:

Airborne transmission (Option B): May occur, especially in poorly ventilated indoor settings or during aerosol-generating procedures, but it is not the primary mode.

Fomite transmission (Option C): The virus can survive on surfaces for varying durations, but transmission via contaminated surfaces is considered secondary and much less efficient.

Faecal-oral route (Option D): Viral RNA has been detected in stool, but no substantial evidence supports it as a significant transmission route.

Key Takeaways:

  • Respiratory droplets are the main transmission mode for SARS-CoV-2
  • Airborne spread is possible but not dominant
  • Fomite and fecal-oral routes are theoretical or minor contributors

questions.text: SARS-CoV-2 is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • SARS-CoV-2, the causative agent of COVID-19, is an enveloped, positive-sense single-stranded RNA (ssRNA) virus
  • It belongs to the Betacoronavirus genus, lineage B, which also includes SARS-CoV-1 and MERS-CoV
  • The virus has a large RNA genome, encoding:
  • Four structural proteins: S (spike), E (envelope), M (membrane), and N (nucleocapsid)
  • A large polyprotein, cleaved into 16 nonstructural proteins
  • The envelope facilitates viral entry via fusion with host cell membranes, and the positive-sense RNA allows direct translation upon infection

Explanation of other options:

Enveloped positive dsDNA (Option A): Incorrect SARS-CoV-2 is RNA, not DNA

Non-enveloped positive dsDNA (Option B): Incorrect on both envelope and genome type

Non-enveloped positive dsRNA (Option D): SARS-CoV-2 is enveloped and ssRNA, not dsRNA

Key Takeaways:

  • SARS-CoV-2 is an enveloped, positive-sense ssRNA virus
  • Encodes structural and nonstructural proteins crucial for replication and immune evasion
  • Member of the Betacoronavirus genus

choices.text: Antigenic shift is reassortment and acquisition of a new genome segment.
Antigenic drift is responsible for new viral strains.
Antigenic shift occurs only in Influenza A viruses

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with fever, myalgia, and cough during the peak of flu season. His rapid influenza test returns positive. While reviewing the epidemiology of influenza, which of the following statements regarding influenza virus evolution is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Antigenic drift involves point mutations in the hemagglutinin (HA) and neuraminidase (NA) genes, leading to minor antigenic changes
  • These small changes result in seasonal epidemics, but not pandemics
  • Pandemics require a major antigenic change, which occurs through antigenic shift.

Explanation of other options:

Antigenic shift is reassortment and acquisition of a new genome segment (Option B):
Antigenic shift occurs when different strains of Influenza A infect the same host, resulting in genomic reassortment and creation of a novel virus with pandemic potential.

Antigenic drift is responsible for new viral strain (Option C): Antigenic drift leads to gradual evolution of viral surface proteins, producing new strains that partially evade existing immunity and require annual vaccine updates.

Antigenic shift occurs only in Influenza A viruses (Option D): Antigenic shift requires co-infection and segment reassortment, which is possible only in Influenza A due to its zoonotic reservoir (e.g., swine, birds).

Key Takeaways:

  • Antigenic drift leads to seasonal epidemics, not pandemics
  • Antigenic shift is the basis for influenza pandemics
  • Only Influenza A undergoes antigenic shift due to zoonotic co-infection capability

questions.text: Most common infection-related graft failure post organ transplantation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Cytomegalovirus (CMV) is the most common infection associated with graft failure following solid organ or hematopoietic stem cell transplantation. Its reactivation in immunocompromised hosts leads to significant morbidity by:

  • Directly damaging graft tissues (especially lung and GI tract),
  • Causing systemic inflammatory response,
  • Leading to bone marrow suppression, which further worsens immune function,
  • And being strongly associated with increased risk of graft rejection and mortality.

Table: Herpesvirus Syndromes in Transplant Recipients

Explanation of other options:

HHV-6 (Option B): Typically causes fever, delayed platelet engraftment, and rarely encephalitis. Not associated with graft failure.

HSV (Option C): HSV-1 and HSV-2 cause mucocutaneous lesions, esophagitis, or hepatitis. They do not lead to graft rejection.

EBV (Option D): Causes post-transplant lymphoproliferative disorder (PTLD), but it is not a common cause of graft failure.

Key Takeaways:

  • CMV is the most common viral pathogen associated with graft failure in transplant patients.
  • CMV reactivation can lead to severe systemic illness, tissue damage, and immune suppression.
  • Other herpesviruses cause important post-transplant syndromes but not direct graft rejection.

questions.text: Anti LKM 3 is seen in which type of viral hepatitis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Liver-kidney microsomal (LKM) autoantibodies are a class of antibodies seen in certain autoimmune and chronic viral hepatitis contexts. These are directed against specific cytochrome P450 enzymes.

  • Anti-LKM3 is particularly associated with chronic Hepatitis D virus (HDV) infection.
  • Though HDV requires HBV for replication, anti-LKM3 marks the immune response directed more specifically in the setting of chronic HDV rather than HBV monoinfection.
  • These antibodies help distinguish HDV in complex serological panels.

Anti-LKM subtypes summary:

Explanation of other options:

Hepatitis A (Option A): This is incorrect. Hepatitis A virus (HAV) causes an acute self-limited illness and does not induce anti-LKM antibodies.

Hepatitis B (Option B): This is incorrect. While HDV requires HBV as a helper virus, anti-LKM3 is not characteristic of HBV alone. HBV is not known to trigger LKM autoimmunity.

Hepatitis C (Option C): This is incorrect. Hepatitis C is associated with anti-LKM1, not anti-LKM3. Anti-LKM1 is also found in autoimmune hepatitis type II.

Key Takeaways:

  • Anti-LKM3 is specifically linked to chronic hepatitis D.
  • Anti-LKM1 is a marker for hepatitis C and autoimmune hepatitis type II.
  • LKM antibodies serve as key immunologic markers to classify hepatitis types.

choices.text: Infection in infancy or early childhood.

questions.text: Risk factors for hepatocellular carcinoma after HCV infection are:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The development of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) after hepatitis C virus (HCV) infection is a multi-step processtypically progressing over decades and is strongly linked with chronic inflammation and cirrhosis.

Chronic hepatitis C infection (Option B) is a well-established risk factor for HCC, especially after progression to cirrhosis, which develops in 20–25% of chronically infected individuals. The chronic inflammation caused by persistent HCV infection leads to fibrosis and ultimately cirrhosis, creating a precancerous hepatic environment.

Infection in infancy or early childhood (Option A) also increases risk because early acquisition of HCV leads to longer duration of infection, and thus a higher cumulative risk of cirrhosis and HCC in adulthood. The earlier the infection is acquired, the longer the liver is exposed to inflammation and the greater the risk of malignant transformation.

Cohort progression estimates from Harrison's:

  • 50-70% of HCV-infected individuals develop chronic hepatitis
  • 20-25% progress to cirrhosis
  • 1-4% per year develop HCC once cirrhosis is established

Explanation of other options:

High level of aminotransferase (Option C): This is incorrect. Elevated aminotransferase levels indicate hepatic inflammation but are not independent predictors of HCC unless accompanied by cirrhosis or fibrosis. Fluctuations in ALT/AST are non-specific and transient.

Key Takeaways:

  • Chronic HCV infection and early-age acquisition are major risk factors for HCC.
  • Cirrhosis is the critical intermediary state that precedes HCC in nearly all cases of HCV-related liver cancer.
  • Aminotransferase levels do not independently predict HCC risk without structural liver disease.

questions.text: Which of the following is associated with autoimmune hepatitis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Hepatitis C is the most well-established viral trigger associated with autoimmune hepatitis (AIH). This is primarily due to molecular mimicry and cross-reactivity between HCV nonstructural proteins (NS3, NS5A) and host liver antigens, especially cytochrome P450 2D6, a known target in type 2 AIH. This immunologic overlap can promote the breakdown of self-tolerance and lead to autoantibody formation.

In contrast, Hepatitis A and Hepatitis B can very rarely lead to a transient autoimmune-like hepatitis post-infection, but the evidence is not robust, and the autoimmune reaction typically resolves without progression to chronic autoimmune hepatitis. Hence, they are not strongly associated with true AIH pathogenesis (Option A and B ruled out).

Explanation of other options:

All of the above (Option D): Incorrect because only Hepatitis C has a well-documented and mechanistic link with AIH.

Key Takeaways:

  • Hepatitis C is associated with autoimmune hepatitis due to molecular mimicry with host autoantigens.
  • Hepatitis A and B are only rarely and transiently linked to AIH-like syndromes.
  • Chronicity and immune activation in HCV make it a significant viral trigger for AIH.

questions.text: Complications of Viral hepatitis does not include:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Viral hepatitis, especially types B and C, are associated with a broad spectrum of extrahepatic manifestations due to immune-mediated mechanisms or direct viral effects. These may affect various organ systems including the pancreas, heart, lungs, bone marrow, and nervous system in the following ways:

  • Pancreatitis (Option A ruled out): Hepatitis viruses, especially hepatitis A and B, have been associated with acute pancreatitis, likely due to immune-related mechanisms or direct viral invasion.
  • Myocarditis (Option B ruled out): Hepatitis C virus in particular can be associated with myocarditis, likely secondary to immune complex deposition or direct myocardial inflammation.
  • Atypical pneumonia (Option C ruled out): This is a rare pulmonary manifestation of viral hepatitis, possibly mediated by immune response or systemic inflammation.

UTI is not a recognized complication of viral hepatitis. It typically results from ascending bacterial infections of the urinary tract, especially in women, and is not mechanistically or epidemiologically linked to hepatitis viruses.

Key Takeaways:

  • Hepatitis viruses can cause multi-organ complications, often immune-mediated.
  • Recognized extrahepatic effects include pancreatitis, myocarditis, atypical pneumonia, aplastic anemia, and neurological syndromes.
  • UTI is not associated with viral hepatitis and thus helps exclude incorrect options in clinical vignettes.

questions.text: Following constitutes clinical stage 4 of HIV disease except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The WHO Clinical Staging system for HIV/AIDS (especially useful where CD4 counts are unavailable) classifies diseases by their severity.

  • Pulmonary TB is classified under Stage 3, not Stage 4, even though TB is AIDS-defining in the CDC classification. It includes TB diagnosed in the lungs confirmed microbiologically or clinically, but without extrapulmonary spread.
  • Esophageal candidiasis is a Stage 4 condition (Option B ruled out) because it represents mucosal involvement beyond the oral cavity and reflects significant immunosuppression.
  • Invasive cervical carcinoma is also considered a Stage 4 condition (Option C ruled out), and it is one of the AIDS-defining malignancies.
  • HIV encephalopathy (Option D ruled out) includes progressive cognitive decline and motor dysfunction in HIV-positive patients and is classified under Stage 4.

Key Takeaways:

  • Stage 4 HIV includes invasive infections (e.g., extrapulmonary TB, candidiasis beyond the mouth), malignancies, and neurological dysfunction.
  • Pulmonary TB, despite being serious, remains under Stage 3 in WHO staging.
  • WHO and NACO staging differ slightly from CDC AIDS-defining illness definitions.

questions.text: M/c pulmonary manifestation in HIV?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most common pulmonary complication of HIV is bacterial pneumonitis (i.e., bacterial pneumonia), due to weakened immune defenses, especially in patients with CD4 counts <200/mm³.

  • Recurrent bacterial pneumonia is an AIDS-defining illness and is more frequently encountered than TB in many settings.
  • Organisms involved include pneumoniae, H. influenzae, and S. aureus.
  • Risk increases with smoking, IV drug use, and low CD4 counts.

Explanation of other options:

Tuberculosis (Option A): Though a major opportunistic infection and AIDS-defining condition, TB is not the most frequent pulmonary manifestation in HIV-positive individuals, especially in developed nations.

Lung abscess (Option B): Rare in HIV, more often seen with aspiration or necrotizing infections; not commonly encountered in routine HIV pulmonary complications.

Acute Bronchitis (Option D): Typically mild and non-specific; not considered a hallmark HIV pulmonary complication.

Key Takeaways:

  • Bacterial pneumonia is the most frequent pulmonary issue in HIV.
  • Recurrent bacterial pneumonia is an AIDS-defining illness.
  • TB is common but not the most frequent in many cohorts.

choices.text: Most patients have CD4 <200 cells/mm3 at time of diagnosis
Most patients will have elevated Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH)
Arterial blood gas (ABG) frequently reveals respiratory alkalosis and widened alveolar arterial oxygen tension difference.
A normal chest radiograph rules out the diagnosis

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about Pneumocystis jiroveci infection?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PCP) is a common opportunistic infection in patients with CD4+ counts <200/mm3, particularly in those not receiving prophylaxis. Diagnosis often requires a high index of suspicion because early findings can be subtle.

  • Most patients have CD4 <200 cells/mm3 (Option A is true): This is the classical risk threshold for PCP, often prompting prophylaxis initiation (e.g., with TMP-SMX).
  • Elevated LDH (Option B is true): This nonspecific marker is frequently elevated in PCP and reflects lung injury, though it lacks specificity.
  • ABG changes (Option C is true): PCP typically causes hypoxia with respiratory alkalosis due to tachypnea, and a widened A-a gradient is almost always present.

A normal chest X-ray does not rule out PCP, especially in early or mild disease. Many patients initially show no radiographic findings, despite significant symptoms and hypoxia. Hence, this makes Option D false.

Explanation of other options:

Most patients have CD4 <200 cells/mm3 (Option A): True. This is the classic threshold at which prophylaxis is recommended, and risk rises significantly.

Most patients will have elevated LDH (Option B): True. LDH is often elevated but nonspecific. Still, it's considered a supportive lab clue in PCP.

ABG frequently reveals respiratory alkalosis and widened A-a gradient (Option C): True. Tachypnea leads to low PaCO (alkalosis), and alveolar-capillary diffusion defect increases A-a gradient.

Key Takeaways:

  • Normal CXR does not exclude PCP, especially early in disease.
  • Respiratory alkalosis + elevated A-a gradient are classic ABG findings.
  • Elevated LDH is common but nonspecific.

questions.text: Most common CVS finding in AIDS is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

With advances in ART (antiretroviral therapy), HIV-infected individuals are living longer, and chronic comorbiditieslike cardiovascular disease have become increasingly prominent. Among these, coronary artery disease (CAD) is now the most common cardiovascular manifestation in AIDS.

  • HIV infection causes chronic systemic inflammation and endothelial dysfunction, accelerating atherogenesis.
  • Certain antiretroviral drugs (like protease inhibitors) contribute to dyslipidemia, insulin resistance, and metabolic syndrome, all of which increase the risk of CAD.
  • Thus, CAD is now the most frequent cardiovascular complication in AIDS patients, especially those with long-standing, treated infection.

Explanation of other options:

Cardiomyopathy (Option B): Seen in advanced or untreated HIV, often related to myocarditis or nutritional deficiencies (like selenium). Less common than CAD in the current ART era.

Infective Endocarditis (Option C): More commonly associated with IV drug use rather than HIV itself. It's not the most common CVS manifestation of AIDS.

Congestive Heart Failure (Option D): Usually a consequence of HIV-associated cardiomyopathy or ischemic heart disease, but not the primary or most frequent manifestation.

Key Takeaways:

  • CAD is the most common CVS manifestation in treated HIV/AIDS.
  • Chronic HIV infection contributes to inflammation-induced atherosclerosis.
  • ART itself can raise metabolic cardiovascular risk.

questions.text: Identify the causative organism for rash shown below
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image shows multiple flesh-colored, dome-shaped papules with central umbilication, which is characteristic of Molluscum contagiosum, a viral infection caused by a poxvirus.

  • The lesions are typically small, smooth, and umbilicated, also described as "dimple rash".
  • Transmission occurs via direct skin-to-skin contact, including sexual contact and contact sports.
  • Common in children, but also seen in immunocompromised individuals, including HIV/AIDS patients, where lesions may be larger and widespread.
  • It is self-limiting in immunocompetent hosts but may require treatment in immunosuppressed patients.

Explanation of other options:

HPV (Option A): Causes warts (verrucae) that are rough, exophytic, and not umbilicated. Typically not seen as grouped papules with central dimple.

Smallpox (Option B): Characterized by deep-seated vesiculopustular lesions at the same stage of development with significant systemic symptoms and scarring. Now eradicated.

Monkeypox (Option C): Presents with vesiculopustular rash, often with fever, lymphadenopathy, and systemic illness. Lesions often resemble smallpox but involve different stages and often involve palms/soles.

Key Takeaways:

  • Molluscum contagiosum = umbilicated dome-shaped papules.
  • Caused by a poxvirus, not HPV.
  • Frequently seen in children and HIV patients.

questions.text: Human parvovirus B19 causes pure red cell aplasia in
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Human parvovirus B19 infects and destroys erythroid progenitor cells in the bone marrow, which can lead to pure red cell aplasia (PRCA).

In immunocompetent individuals, the infection is usually self-limiting. However, in immunodeficient patients, the virus persists because of impaired humoral immunity, leading to chronic anemia with reticulocytopenia.

  • These patients often lack B19-specific IgG due to immune dysfunction.
  • Bone marrow typically shows giant pronormoblasts.
  • Persistent infection leads to a sustained decrease in erythropoiesis, causing chronic pure red cell aplasia.

Explanation of other options:

Healthy children (Option A): Parvovirus B19 typically causes erythema infectiosum (fifth disease) with mild anemia, not PRCA. Bone marrow recovers as the infection resolves.

Healthy adults (Option B): May present with arthralgia or arthritis, especially in women. PRCA is rare and usually transient if it occurs.

Fetuses (Option D): Infection may cause hydrops fetalis due to severe anemia, but it is not termed PRCA; the pathophysiology and clinical picture are distinct.

Key Takeaways:

  • Pure red cell aplasia from B19 is a chronic condition in immunodeficient hosts.
  • Bone marrow shows giant pronormoblasts with reticulocytopenia.
  • Other presentations vary by immune status and age.

questions.text: First line oral drug for Chronic hepatitis B is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

For chronic hepatitis B, the preferred first-line oral antiviral agents are Entecavir and Tenofovir, due to their potent antiviral activity and high barrier to resistance.

  • Entecavir is a guanosine nucleoside analogue that inhibits HBV polymerase and is effective in both treatment-naive and lamivudine-resistant patients.
  • It is well tolerated, with minimal nephrotoxicity and low risk of resistance in treatment-naive individuals.

Explanation of other options:

Lamivudine (Option B): Though previously used, it is now less preferred due to high rates of resistance with long-term use.

Adefovir (Option C): Also has lower potency and a higher risk of nephrotoxicity compared to entecavir and tenofovir; thus, not considered first-line.

Ritonavir (Option D): An HIV protease inhibitor used as a booster, not active against HBV.

Key Takeaways:

  • Entecavir and Tenofovir are the preferred first-line oral agents for chronic HBV.
  • Drugs like lamivudine and adefovir are outdated due to resistance and side effect profiles.
  • Treatment decisions also depend on HBV DNA levels, ALT levels, and fibrosis stage.

questions.text: Most common microbial trigger for Type 1 DM are all except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Type 1 Diabetes Mellitus (T1DM) is an autoimmune disease often triggered by environmental factors in genetically predisposed individuals. Among these, viral infections have been most consistently implicated as potential triggers for islet cell autoimmunity.

  • Coxsackie viruses, particularly Coxsackie B, are among the most widely studied and proposed viral triggers for T1DM.
  • Rubella virus has been linked to congenital rubella syndrome, which includes β-cell destruction and subsequent diabetes.
  • Enteroviruses (which include Coxsackieviruses) are also associated with molecular mimicry and direct islet cell cytolysis.

Chicken pox, caused by varicella-zoster virus, is not a recognized microbial trigger for T1DM. There is no consistent epidemiological or mechanistic link between VZV and autoimmune β-cell destruction.

Explanation of other options:

Coxsackie (Option A): Known enterovirus subgroup implicated in T1DM pathogenesis via molecular mimicry and direct cytolytic effects.

Rubella (Option B): Especially in congenital infections, rubella is associated with later development of T1DM.

Enterovirus (Option C): A broader class of viruses, including Coxsackie B, consistently implicated in T1DM autoimmunity.

Key Takeaways:

  • Coxsackie, rubella, and enteroviruses are linked with T1DM onset.
  • Chicken pox (VZV) is not associated with autoimmune β-cell damage.
  • Viral triggers may act years before clinical onset.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most sensitive test for diagnosing tubercular pleural effusion?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In tuberculous pleural effusion, the fluid typically shows an exudative profile with lymphocytic predominance, and the most sensitive test for diagnosis is measuring adenosine deaminase (ADA) levels.

  • ADA is an enzyme involved in purine metabolism and is released by activated T-lymphocytes in TB.
  • An ADA level >45 IU/L in lymphocytic pleural effusion has high sensitivity (often >90%) for TB, especially in high-prevalence settings.
  • While not completely specific, it is very sensitive, rapid, and inexpensive.

Explanation of other options:

Gene Xpert (Option A): Has high specificity but low sensitivity for pleural TB due to low bacillary load in the pleural fluid.

Xpert Ultra (Option B): More sensitive than GeneXpert, but still less sensitive than ADA in pleural effusions due to paucibacillary nature of TB in the pleural space.

IFN-gamma (Option D): Very specific and sensitive but not widely available and more expensive; ADA remains preferred in most practical settings.

Key Takeaways:

  • ADA >45 IU/L is the most sensitive test for tubercular pleural effusion.
  • Pleural TB is usually paucibacillary, making molecular tests less sensitive.
  • IFN-γ assays are good but not routinely used due to cost and availability.

choices.text: Continue hand washing for a further 20 minutes
Test for hepatitis B and C

questions.text: A nurse has a needlestick injury after taking blood from a patient known to be HIV positive. What is the most appropriate immediate management after hand washing for 10 minutes?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most appropriate immediate step after a needlestick injury involving known HIV-positive blood- following local wound care- is initiation of post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) with antiretroviral therapy.

  • The risk of seroconversion after percutaneous exposure is about 3%, but this increases with deep injury, visible blood, or a source patient with high viral load.
  • PEP should be started ideally within 1-2 hours, and no later than 72 hours, for maximum efficacy.
  • The recommended regimen includes two NRTIs plus a third agent, commonly an integrase inhibitor or protease inhibitor (e.g., tenofovir + emtricitabine + raltegravir).
  • Continued monitoring, baseline and follow-up HIV testing, and psychosocial support are also part of the management.

Explanation of other options:

Continue hand washing for a further 20 minutes (Option A): Hand washing beyond the initial 10 minutes provides no additional benefit and delays urgent PEP initiation.

Test for hepatitis B and C (Option C): Important as part of follow-up testing, but not the most immediate step after exposure.

Blood cultures (Option D): Not relevant in post-exposure prophylaxis. Blood cultures are used to diagnose bacteremia or sepsis, not for assessing HIV exposure.

Key Takeaways:

  • Start antiretroviral therapy (PEP) immediately after HIV exposure via needlestick.
  • Timing is critical ideally within 1-2 hours, no later than 72 hours.
  • Additional testing (HBV, HCV, HIV serology) is important but follows PEP initiation.

questions.text: A 20-year-old student presents with a 5-day history of fever and sore throat. His doctor started him on penicillin, but there was no improvement. On examination his temperature is 38.8°C. He has grey plaques on his tonsils, cervical lymphadenopathy and splenomegaly. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This patient presents with persistent sore throat, fever, gray plaques on tonsils, cervical lymphadenopathy, and splenomegaly, which are classic features of infectious mononucleosis, caused by the Epstein-Barr virus (EBV).

  • It commonly affects young adults, often following close contact (kissing disease).
  • Patients typically have fatigue, pharyngitis, tonsillar exudates, and generalized lymphadenopathy.
  • Splenomegaly occurs in ~60% of cases and is an important diagnostic clue.
  • Lack of response to penicillin and rash with ampicillin (if mistakenly given) are further diagnostic hints.
  • Atypical lymphocytosis and positive Monospot (heterophile antibody) test confirm the diagnosis.

Explanation of other options:

Streptococcus infection (Option A): While streptococcal pharyngitis causes sore throat and tonsillar exudates, it usually improves with penicillin and does not cause splenomegaly.

Borrelia vincenti infection (Option B): This refers to acute necrotizing ulcerative gingivitis (Vincent angina), which presents with ulcers, foul breath, and necrotic gum margins, not gray tonsillar plaques or splenomegaly.

Diphtheria (Option C): Causes gray membrane over the tonsils and soft palate, but is very rare due to vaccination and does not present with generalized lymphadenopathy or splenomegaly.

Key Takeaways:

  • Infectious mononucleosis presents with fever, pharyngitis, lymphadenopathy, and splenomegaly.
  • EBV is the causative virus; Monospot test helps in diagnosis.
  • Unnecessary use of ampicillin/penicillin can cause a maculopapular rash in these patients.

questions.text: Which of the following is seen in encephalitic rabies?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Encephalitic rabies, also called "furious rabies," is the more common form and is marked by early and severe brainstem involvement. This involvement underlies the hallmark features such as hydrophobia, aerophobia, and autonomic dysfunction.

As the infection spreads within the brainstem, it disrupts vital centers controlling cardiovascular, respiratory, and neuroendocrine regulation, leading to a range of systemic complications:

  • SIADH (Syndrome of Inappropriate Antidiuretic Hormone Secretion) occurs due to hypothalamic-pituitary axis involvement, leading to hyponatremia and water retention.
  • Diabetes insipidus may also occur in later stages due to posterior pituitary dysfunction, leading to polyuria and hypernatremia.
  • Cardiac arrhythmias result from brainstem autonomic dysfunction or rabies myocarditis, and may manifest as bradyarrhythmias or tachyarrhythmias.

Thus, all of the above complications are recognized sequelae of advanced encephalitic rabies.

Explanation of other options:

SIADH (Option A): True. Caused by hypothalamic-pituitary dysregulation during CNS involvement.

Diabetes insipidus (Option B): True. Due to posterior pituitary damage; may occur in the late phase.

Cardiac arrhythmia (Option C): True. Due to brainstem autonomic disruption or myocarditis.

Key Takeaways:

  • Encephalitic rabies leads to severe brainstem dysfunction with autonomic instability.
  • Both SIADH and diabetes insipidus may occur as opposite spectrum disorders of neuroendocrine regulation.
  • Arrhythmias reflect either brainstem autonomic injury or direct cardiac involvement.

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman with known HIV/AIDS (CD4 lymphocyte = 106/ uL and viral load = 35,000/mL)presents with painful growths on the side of her tongue as shown in Figure. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanationor:

In patients with advanced HIV/AIDS and CD4 count <200/µL, the presence of white, non-removable lesions on the lateral borders of the tongue strongly suggests oral hairy leukoplakia.

  • It is caused by Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV) reactivation in immunocompromised hosts, particularly with T-cell deficiency.
  • Lesions are typically white, vertical corrugated, or "hairy" plaques that cannot be scraped off.
  • It is not premalignant and typically resolves with antiretroviral therapy; antivirals like acyclovir may help, but ART is curative.

Explanation of other options:

Aphthous ulcers (Option A): Painful, shallow ulcers with erythematous halo, usually on non-keratinized mucosa like the buccal mucosa or inner lips not along the lateral tongue and not white plaques.

Herpes stomatitis (Option C): Caused by HSV; presents as painful vesicles or ulcers on erythematous bases. Lesions are typically not white plaques and often affect the gingiva and hard palate.

Oral candidiasis (Option D): Common in HIV; presents as white curd-like plaques that can be scraped off, often leaving an erythematous base unlike hairy leukoplakia.

Key Takeaways:

  • Oral hairy leukoplakia = white, lateral tongue lesions in T-cell deficiency (CD4 <200).
  • Cannot be scraped off (vs candidiasis).
  • Caused by EBV, resolves with ART.

questions.text: What is the most common clinical manifestation of mumps?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most common clinical manifestation of mumps is acute, painful swelling of the parotid glands. This salivary gland involvement is typically bilateral, although it may start on one side and involve the other later.

  • Parotitis occurs in over 90% of symptomatic mumps cases.
  • The swelling is often accompanied by fever, malaise, and headache, and may last for 7-10 days.
  • Trismus and earache may be present due to parotid inflammation.

Explanation of other options:

Epididymo-Orchitis (Option A): Seen in 15-30% of postpubertal males, but it is the second most commonmanifestation not the most common.

Rash (Option C): Not typical of mumps. If present, a rash suggests an alternate or coexisting viral illness.

Hepatosplenomegaly (Option D): Rare in mumps and not a characteristic finding.

Key Takeaways:

  • Parotid swelling is the hallmark and most common symptom of mumps.
  • Epididymo-orchitis is second most common, seen in postpubertal males.
  • Rash and hepatosplenomegaly are not typical features.

questions.text: What is the Most common hematologic abnormality in HIV infected patients?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Anemia is the most frequent hematologic abnormality observed in patients with HIV infection, seen across all stages of the disease. Its presence often reflects chronic inflammation, opportunistic infections, drug toxicity (e.g., zidovudine), or bone marrow suppression.

  • It may be normocytic normochromic or reflect iron deficiency, B12/folate deficiency, or anemia of chronic disease.
  • Anemia in HIV is associated with higher morbidity and mortality and is considered an independent marker of poor prognosis.

Explanation of other options:

Leucopenia (Option B): Also occurs in HIV, especially late-stage disease, but is less common than anemia and often reflects advanced immunosuppression.

Thrombocytopenia (Option C): Can be seen in early or late HIV due to immune destruction or marrow suppression, but is not as frequent as anemia.

Thrombocytosis (Option D): Not a typical finding in HIV and usually reflects reactive processes unrelated to HIV itself.

Key Takeaways:

  • Anemia is the most common hematologic abnormality in HIV.
  • It reflects underlying inflammation, nutritional deficiencies, or drug toxicity.
  • Anemia is an independent predictor of poor outcomes in HIV-infected individuals.

questions.text: Spot the diagnosis in the HIV patient.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image shows reddish-purple, vascular nodular lesions on the hard palate, a classic presentation of oral Kaposi's sarcoma one of the AIDS-defining illnesses in advanced HIV infection. It is caused by HHV-8 (Human Herpesvirus 8) and is more common in patients with CD4 counts <200/μL.

  • Lesions may occur anywhere in the oral cavity but are particularly common on the hard palate.
  • These are non-painful, non-scrapable, and appear vascular or violaceous.
  • Diagnosis is clinical but may be confirmed by biopsy showing spindle cells and angioproliferation.

Explanation of other options:

Thrush (Option A): Characterized by white curd-like plaques on an erythematous base, typically on the tongue or buccal mucosa, and can be scraped off.

Aphthous ulcer (Option C): Appears as painful, round or oval ulcers with an erythematous halo, usually on non-keratinized mucosa, not as vascular plaques.

Hairy cell leukemia (Option D): Irrelevant here; it is a hematologic malignancy and does not present with oral lesions. The intended choice may have been oral hairy leukoplakia, which is different.

Key Takeaways:

  • Oral Kaposi's sarcoma = violaceous, vascular nodules, especially on the hard palate.
  • HHV-8 is the causative virus.

Occurs in advanced HIV, often with CD4 <200/μL

questions.text: What is the most common opportunistic infection globally in HIV-infected individuals?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Mycobacterium tuberculosis remains the most common opportunistic infection worldwide in individuals infected with HIV, especially in low- and middle-income countries where both infections are highly endemic.

  • HIV increases the risk of primary TB, reactivation, and rapid progression from latent to active disease.
  • Co-infection accelerates the progression of both diseases and worsens outcomes.
  • TB can occur at any CD4 count, but risk increases as CD4 declines, especially <350 cells/µL.
  • Presentations may be pulmonary or extrapulmonary (e.g., lymph nodes, CNS, miliary TB).

Explanation of other options:

PCP (Option B): Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia is a common opportunistic infection in developed countries, especially when CD4 <200, but is not the most common globally.

CMV (Option C): Typically occurs at very low CD4 counts (<50) and causes retinitis, colitis, or encephalitis, but is less common overall than TB.

Candida (Option D): Oral thrush is very common, but systemic candidiasis is far less frequent than TB. It is also less likely to cause serious systemic illness early in HIV.

Key Takeaways:

  • TB is the leading global opportunistic infection in HIV.
  • Can present at any stage of HIV, including with normal CD4 counts.
  • Co-management of TB and HIV is critical in high-burden regions.

questions.text: Maternal HIV transmission to the fetus occurs most commonly during?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Perinatal transmission which includes labor and delivery is the most common window during which maternal HIV is transmitted to the fetus. This is due to the infant's direct exposure to maternal blood and genital secretions during childbirth.

  • Without any intervention, the overall risk of mother-to-child transmission (MTCT) is around 15-45%, and the majority of transmission occurs intrapartum.
  • Antiretroviral therapy (ART), elective cesarean delivery (if viral load is high), and formula feeding (in settings where safe) can reduce this risk to <1%.

Explanation of other options:

Prenatal period (Option A): In utero transmission does occur but is less common than perinatal transmission.

Postnatal period (Option C): HIV can be transmitted via breastfeeding, especially with mixed feeding or mastitis, but this is less common than during delivery unless ART is not given.

During early infancy (Option D): Not a standard phase; transmission at this time would be categorized under postnatal(e.g., breastfeeding-related).

Key Takeaways:

  • Perinatal (intrapartum) period is the most common time for HIV transmission.
  • ART and proper obstetric/neonatal interventions drastically reduce MTCT.
  • Breastfeeding is a postnatal risk in resource-limited

questions.text: Among circumcised men, warts are Most commonly found on Which part of genitalia?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In circumcised men, anogenital warts, caused primarily by human papillomavirus (HPV) types 6 and 11, are most commonly located on the penile shaft. This distribution reflects the lack of prepuce and altered epithelial exposure in circumcised individuals.

  • The shaft becomes the primary exposed mucocutaneous area post-circumcision.
  • Other frequent sites include the urethral meatus, and lesions may extend proximally.

Explanation of other options:

Glans (Option A): Can be involved, especially in uncircumcised men, but less common than shaft involvement in circumcised individuals.

Prepuce (Option B): Absent in circumcised men, making this an unlikely site.

Scrotum (Option D): Can have warts, but far less commonly than the penile shaft.

Key Takeaways:

  • In circumcised men, penile shaft is the most common site for genital warts.
  • HPV 6 and 11 are the usual etiologic agents.
  • Site distribution varies based on circumcision status.

choices.text: Secondary bacterial superinfection of the skin

questions.text: What is the most common infectious complication of varicella?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most common infectious complication of varicella (chickenpox) is secondary bacterial infection of skin lesions, particularly in children who tend to scratch their vesicular eruptions.

  • These infections are most often caused by Streptococcus pyogenes (Group A strep) and Staphylococcus aureus, including MRSA strains.
  • Superinfection may present with erythema, warmth, purulence, or even progress to cellulitis or necrotizing fasciitis in severe cases.

Explanation of other options:

Pneumonia (Option B): A serious but less common complication, more likely in adults, pregnant women, or immunocompromised patients.

Vaginitis (Option C): Not a recognized complication of varicella.

Urethritis (Option D): Also not a typical complication of varicella.

Key Takeaways:

  • Skin superinfection is the most frequent infectious complication of varicella.
  • Caused mainly by Streptococcus pyogenes and Staphylococcus aureus.
  • Proper hygiene and avoiding scratching reduce risk.

questions.text: What are the most common clinical manifestations of first-episode HSV-1 infection?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most common clinical manifestation of primary (first-episode) HSV-1 infection is gingivostomatitis, especially in children and young adults.

  • It typically presents with painful oral ulcers, inflamed gums (gingivitis), fever, malaise, and cervical lymphadenopathy.
  • Lesions may involve the buccal mucosa, tongue, palate, and gingiva.
  • This contrasts with reactivation, which often manifests as herpes labialis (cold sores).

Explanation of other options:

Corneal ulcers (Option B): Seen in herpes keratitis, more common in recurrent infections, not typical of primary HSV-1.

Fever (Option C): Common but non-specific; often accompanies gingivostomatitis but is not the most defining feature.

Vesicular lesions over face (Option D): May be seen, but are not the hallmark of primary HSV-1 infection.

Key Takeaways:

  • Primary HSV-1 infection most often presents as gingivostomatitis.
  • Recurrent disease typically causes herpes labialis (cold sores).
  • Systemic symptoms like fever may be present but are not specific.

questions.text: Most common infectious agents that cause facial palsy is?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most common infectious causes of facial palsy are Herpes simplex virus type 1 (HSV-1) and Varicella-zoster virus (VZV).

  • HSV-1 is linked with Bell's palsy, the most common form of idiopathic unilateral facial paralysis.
  • VZV causes Ramsay Hunt syndrome (herpes zoster oticus), characterized by facial palsy, vesicular rash in the ear canal or pinna, and often hearing loss or vertigo.
  • Although HSV-1 is slightly more common overall, VZV is specifically the most well-established infectious agent with classical imaging and clinical findings in facial palsy, especially in syndromic cases.

Explanation of other options:

Epstein-Barr (Option A): Can occasionally cause facial palsy, particularly during mononucleosis, but is much less common.

Borrelia (Option B): Causes facial palsy in Lyme disease, especially in endemic areas, but is geographically limited and less frequent overall.

CMV (Option C): May cause facial palsy in neonates or immunocompromised patients but is not a leading cause in the general population.

Key Takeaways:

  • VZV and HSV-1 are the most common viral causes of facial palsy.
  • Ramsay Hunt syndrome from VZV includes facial palsy with vesicular rash and possible auditory symptoms.
  • Lyme disease should be considered in endemic regions for bilateral palsy.

questions.text: Which of the following opportunistic infections is most typical of HIV infection with a CD4 count less than 50 cells/µL?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In advanced HIV infection, the risk of specific opportunistic infections (OIs) correlates strongly with declining CD4+ T-cell counts. At CD4 <50 cells/μL, patients are particularly vulnerable to disseminated Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC) disease, which is a hallmark OI in this range.

  • MAC infection typically presents with fever, night sweats, weight loss, and hepatosplenomegaly, and often involves bone marrow and liver.
  • Diagnosis is made via blood cultures or biopsy.
  • Prophylaxis with azithromycin or clarithromycin is recommended when CD4 <50.

Explanation of other options:

Mucormycosis (Option A): Typically associated with uncontrolled diabetes mellitus or neutropenia, not commonly seen in HIV patients.

BK virus nephropathy (Option B): Occurs primarily in renal transplant recipients; it is not a recognized OI in HIV patients.

Nocardiosis (Option C): Can occur but is unusual in HIV and much less common than MAC at CD4 <50.

Key Takeaways:

  • MAC disease is the classic OI seen at CD4 <50/μL.
  • Mucormycosis and BK virus are unrelated to HIV-based immunosuppression.
  • Nocardiosis is rare in HIV and not typically associated with CD4 <50.

choices.text: Dengue virus infection, classic with preeclampsia

questions.text: A 24-year-old female experienced sudden onset fever, severe headache, eye pain, nausea, vomiting, myalgia, and arthralgia. By the next day, the joint and muscle pain became severe. Two days later, she sought medical attention. The examination showed an ill-appearing woman, alert but in apparent pain. Temperature was 100.5° F, pulse 104/ minute, blood pressure 92/50 mm Hg, and respirations 28/minute. Multiple petechiae appeared on her left arm distal to where the blood pressure cuff was applied. Laboratory testing showed WBC of 1500/°L and platelet count of 55,000/µL. Hemoglobin was 19 g/dL. Prothrombin time was 22 seconds. The pregnancy test was positive. Dengue virus serology was positive for IgG antibodies to serotype 1 as well as for IgM and IgG antibodies to serotype 2. The diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This patient presents with classic features of dengue fever  fever, headache, myalgia, arthralgia, and nausea. However, key findings point toward progression to dengue hemorrhagic fever (DHF):

  • Petechiae appearing after BP cuff inflation indicates a positive tourniquet test, a diagnostic sign of increased capillary fragility, which is characteristic of DHF.
  • Thrombocytopenia (55,000/µL) and prolonged prothrombin time (22 sec) support coagulopathy.
  • Hemoconcentration (hemoglobin 19 g/dL) is evidence of plasma leakage, a hallmark of DHF.
  • Serologic evidence of secondary dengue infection (IgG+ for serotype 1 and both IgM/IgG for serotype 2) increases risk for severe manifestations due to antibody-dependent enhancement.

Explanation of other options:

Dengue virus infection, classic (Option A): Does not include hemorrhagic features, capillary leak, or coagulopathy, all of which are present here.

Dengue virus infection, shock syndrome (Option C): Patient has low-normal BP but not frank shock (no hypotension or organ hypoperfusion). Thus, DSS is premature.

Dengue virus infection, classic with preeclampsia (Option D): Pregnancy test is positive, but no signs of preeclampsia(e.g., hypertension or proteinuria). The low BP and petechiae suggest DHF, not preeclampsia.

Key Takeaways:

  • DHF is defined by thrombocytopenia, plasma leakage, and bleeding signs.
  • Positive tourniquet test, hemoconcentration, and coagulopathy are key diagnostic indicators.
  • Secondary dengue infections carry higher risk for DHF due to antibody-dependent enhancement.

questions.text: The most probable diagnosis of an adult with viral acute gastroenteritis related to a food-borne outbreak is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Norovirus is the most common cause of viral acute gastroenteritis in adults, especially when associated with food-borne outbreaks. It is highly contagious and spreads rapidly in settings such as cruise ships, schools, nursing homes, and food-handling environments.

  • Transmission occurs via contaminated food, water, surfaces, or person-to-person contact.
  • It causes acute-onset vomiting, watery diarrhea, abdominal cramps, and often low-grade fever.
  • The illness is typically self-limiting within 48-72 hours.

Explanation of other options:

Rotavirus (Option A): Common cause of gastroenteritis in infants and young children, but rare in adults due to prior immunity.

Poliovirus (Option C): Causes neurologic disease (e.g., flaccid paralysis), not gastroenteritis. Its mild initial presentation may include GI symptoms, but it is not a cause of food-borne outbreaks of gastroenteritis.

All of the above (Option D): Incorrect, as only norovirus is the major agent among the listed for adult food-borne outbreaks.

Key Takeaways:

  • Norovirus is the leading cause of food-borne viral gastroenteritis in adults.
  • Rotavirus is more common in children; poliovirus does not cause gastroenteritis outbreaks.
  • Transmission is via fecal-oral route, often involving contaminated food.
